Award.AwardTitle: SBE: Small: Protecting Privacy in Cyberspace: From Neuroscience Investigations to Behavioral Interventions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key characteristic of cyberspace is the collection of large amounts of data, and people's privacy becomes vulnerable given the hyper-connectivity of cyberspace and the ease of accessing data. This project aims to enhance the safety and trustworthiness of cyberspace by designing choice architecture interventions informed by the neural processes underlying privacy to help people make better decisions about their privacy in cyberspace. Choice architecture is gaining popularity among academics and policy makers as a means to design the presentation of options to promote decisions that benefit both individuals and society. This project aims to uncover the neural correlates of privacy concerns to identify the cognitive and emotional processes that guide privacy behaviors in cyberspace. By using functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) to characterize the neural processes underlying privacy, this project aims to expand the toolbox of privacy researchers by introducing new theories and methods from neuroscience. By investigating the neural correlates of privacy concerns, this project seeks to inform future choice architecture interventions to encourage people to protect their privacy. Results will be disseminated broadly through conferences across several disciplines. Special focus will be given on disseminating findings beyond academics to non-research audiences, especially with respect to informing policy. Finally, this project aims to advance research and teaching at Temple University by providing a mentoring environment for students at all levels, including under-represented groups, to study privacy in cyberspace.

Privacy concerns are unintended consequences of the Internet that prevent a safe and trustworthy cyberspace. There is a tradeoff between privacy risks associated with disclosing private information and the benefits from such disclosure (termed "privacy calculus"). Moreover, the "privacy paradox" states that although people self-report that privacy is critical to them, they often disclose more private information online, inconsistent with their privacy concerns. However, the neural processes that underlie people's decisions to protect their privacy are unclear. This project breaks new ground in privacy research by uncovering the neural correlates of privacy concerns with fMRI and using these insights to design choice architecture interventions to protect people's privacy in cyberspace. Specifically, it examines the neural processes underlying privacy concerns to help people better balance their privacy risks versus disclosure benefits in their privacy calculus to overcome the privacy paradox. This project will characterize the psychological processes that guide people's decisions to disclose their private information by identifying the neural correlates of privacy concerns with fMRI. This work will inform choice architecture interventions to encourage people to make decisions about their privacy in cyberspace to better match their privacy concerns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes pertaining to Intellectual Merit

The first major outcome of this project is to illustrate the neural underpinnings of the privacy calculus and the privacy paradox by investigating the cognitive and emotional mechanisms that underlie people’s decisions to disclose their private information in cyberspace. By leveraging functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), we investigated and identified the neural correlates of privacy concerns (where privacy concerns are mapped into the brain). Specifically, consistent with our theorization of the neural correlates of privacy concerns, we first showed that putative emotional processing regions, specifically the anterior insula and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex, exhibited higher activation in response to higher privacy concerns. These areas are typically implicated in negative anticipation and negative emotions, consistent with the notion that these emotional processes are likely to underlie people’s privacy concerns. Heightened activation was also observed in the temporoparietal junction and prefrontal cortex. These regions are implicated in a range of cognitive processes, including directing attention to potentially relevant or threatening information. Second, our analyses also identified the brain areas that positively correlate with perceived attractiveness of the benefits, notably the ventral striatum and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex. These two areas are typically implicated in reward processing, consistent with the notion that benefits of disclosure elicit anticipated reward processes. Third, our analyses also revealed that activation in parietal and lateral prefrontal areas correlate with willingness to disclose information, suggesting these areas may integrate signals from the other areas identified to guide information disclosure decisions. Subsequent connectivity analyses revealed that these regions coordinate with one another and with dorsal anterior cingulate cortex when guiding decisions to disclose. Taken as a whole, these analyses identify a network of cortical brain regions involved in integrating information to guide decisions about private information. 

Second, our behavioral findings indicate that people integrate information about both the risks and benefits of disclosure when deciding whether to share private information. Specifically, the attractiveness of the benefits is positively associated with the willingness to disclose private information, while the intrusiveness of the question is negative associated with the willingness to disclose private information.

Taken together, these results are consistent with the theory of the privacy calculus, where people’s decision-making is based on a risk-benefit analysis. In addition, we found that the trade-off used when people integrate this competing information tracks real-world online behaviors and knowledge related to privacy. To our knowledge, this is the very first study to examine and delineate the neural correlates of privacy concerns. We anticipate these novel findings will help inform debates regarding the psychology and neuroscience underlying decisions to disclose private information. 

 

Project Outcomes pertaining to Broader Impacts

Concerns regarding privacy have become commonplace as cyberspace has permeated more areas of people’s lives, and it still remains unclear how people make decisions regarding when and how to share private information. Having identified the neural underpinnings of privacy, the ultimate outcome of this project is to inform the intelligent design of behavioral interventions to help people to protect their privacy in cyberspace. Our findings provide the basis and theoretical understanding, based on the neuroscience of our brain, of how these behavioral interventions should be designed to be effective in helping people to protect their privacy in cyberspace. Specifically, a clearer understanding of the psychological processes involved can also suggest effective choice architecture behavioral interventions to encourage people to avoid exposing themselves to excessive privacy risks from information disclosure (improving the privacy calculus) and to behave consistently with their privacy concerns to overcome the privacy paradox and better protect their privacy in cyberspace.
